title: The Holiness and Reign of God
shortSummary: Psalm 99 celebrates the sovereign reign and holiness of the LORD, emphasizing His justice, mercy, and the reverence due to Him. It recalls the faithful leadership of Moses, Aaron, and Samuel as examples of those who called upon God and received His answers. The chapter calls believers to worship God with awe and to honor His righteous rule.
timeline: c. 10th century BC - United Monarchy period, reflecting Israel's worship in Zion

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The great prophet and leader of Israel who interceded for the people and received God's law.

keyCharacters.name: Aaron
keyCharacters.description: Brother of Moses and the first high priest, representing the priestly mediation before God.

keyCharacters.name: Samuel
keyCharacters.description: A prophet and judge who faithfully called upon the LORD and led Israel in obedience.

definitions.definition: Heavenly beings depicted as guardians of God's throne, symbolizing His holiness and majesty.
A metaphor for God's earthly dwelling place, often understood as the temple or Zion where God’s presence rests.
Justice administered with fairness and righteousness, reflecting God's moral governance.
The visible manifestation of God's presence during the Exodus, guiding and communicating with His people.

outline.heading: The LORD's Sovereign Reign and Holiness
outline.description: The psalm opens by declaring God's reign over all the earth, His presence between the cherubims, and calls the people to tremble and praise His holy name.

outline.heading: God’s Just Rule in Zion
outline.description: This section highlights God's strength in loving justice and establishing righteousness, urging the people to exalt and worship Him at His footstool.

outline.heading: Faithful Leaders Who Called Upon God
outline.description: Moses, Aaron, and Samuel are commended as faithful priests and prophets who called on God and obeyed His commandments, demonstrating a model of godly leadership.

outline.heading: God’s Mercy and Justice
outline.description: The psalm closes by affirming God’s forgiving nature despite His righteous vengeance, and calls all to worship Him on His holy hill because He alone is holy.

application: Approach God with reverence and awe, recognizing His sovereign reign over all creation.
Commit to living justly and righteously as a reflection of God’s character in your daily life.
Call upon God in prayer with confidence, trusting that He hears and answers His people.
Worship God sincerely and regularly, honoring His holiness and presence among His people.

keyVerses.text: The LORD reigneth; let the people tremble: he sitteth between the cherubims; let the earth be moved.
keyVerses.significance: This verse establishes God's supreme authority and the reverence due to Him as King over all.

keyVerses.text: The king's strength also loveth judgment; thou dost establish equity, thou executest judgment and righteousness in Jacob.
keyVerses.significance: It highlights God's commitment to justice and righteousness as foundational to His rule.

keyVerses.text: Moses and Aaron among his priests, and Samuel among them that call upon his name; they called upon the LORD, and he answered them.
keyVerses.significance: This verse honors faithful leaders who exemplify prayerful dependence on God.

keyVerses.text: Exalt the LORD our God, and worship at his holy hill; for the LORD our God is holy.
keyVerses.significance: It calls believers to worship God with recognition of His absolute holiness.
